column2: Companion data with the paper "Investigating the impact of adopting Python and C languages for introductory engineering programming courses" submitted to Computer Applications in Engineering Education Journal. If you use this data, please include a reference to the paper.

O1 - Suppose you are hired to develop a program that stores and manages student information at a university. Choose the best alternative that represents an important question to ask at the beginning of the project.
A. How many buildings does the university have?
(B). What information is filled in by students at the time of enrollment?
C. What is the name of the university's founder?
D. How many students use school transport to get to the university?
E. How long has the university existed?
column4:
O3 - Suppose you are hired to develop a program that stores and manages student information at a university. Choose the best alternative to count how many registered students are underage.
A. The program needs to include sequential and iterative commands only - conditionals are not necessary. In iterative commands, particular preference should be given to the while statement over the for statement.
B. The program needs to include conditional commands only - iteratives are not necessary.
C. The program needs to include iterative commands only - conditionals are not necessary. In iterative commands, particular preference should be given to the for statement over the while statement.
D. The program needs to include sequential, conditional and iterative commands. In iterative commands, particular preference should be given to the while statement over the for statement.
(E). The program needs to include sequential, conditional and iterative commands. In iterative commands, particular preference should be given to the for statement over the while statement.
column6:
O5 - Suppose you are hired to develop a program that stores and manages student information at a university. Choose the best alternative to permanently store the students' data.
A. Save the information of registered students in structs / classes, as long as each struct / class is responsible for a characteristic of the student.
B. Save the information of registered students in text files, where the information of different students is mixed between commas, on the same line.
C. Save the information of registered students in structs / classes, where the main information is separated by fields / attributes.
(D). Save the information of registered students in text files, where each student is on a line with their information separated by commas.
E. Save the information of registered students in strings, where this information must be separated by blank spaces.
